segments.text: Geography 311 class at the home of Mary Lancaster 303 Dexter College Station.
Mary Lancaster 303 Dexter College Station.
This is for the Geography 311 class.
I'm interviewing Mary Lancaster, and she's going to give us a short biographical sketch before we begin the interview.
Thank you, Becky.
I was born Mary Laverne Whiteside in Teague, Texas, which is in Freestone County.
In 1930, I was born to Matty Ora and Talmadge Whiteside.
who had lived in Texas all of their lives, who had been married for 22 years without children, and finally, in their middle age, had one child.
I lived in Freestone County for several years and then moved to Normandy, Texas, which is in Leon County, when I was eight.
and lived there until I finished high school.
Then I went to Baylor University for four years, and then came to Bryan and College Station to work as a Girl Scout Executive Director.
Here I met my husband, who had lived here all of his life, and we were married.
I married William B. Lancaster, and we have now had three children.
And we live at 303 Dexter and College Station and have lived here almost all of our married life and hope to the rest of our lives.
Okay.
How many or how long has your family been in this general area?
My grandparents and their parents came to Texas.
They came either from
Alabama, or Mississippi, soon after the Civil War.
Most often came, I suppose, because most of everything they had worked for was destroyed there, or the frontier here seemed more profitable.
One group of great-grandparents came to Arkansas and settled for about 10 years, and then came on to Texas.
leaving four little children buried in Arkansas, I remember.
Then another set of great-grandparents came from Mississippi down and settled in the lower eastern part of Texas, which is now Beaumont.
They settled there for a few years, but because the climate was so humid and damp and they felt it was not healthy,
They sold their land there for a penny an acre, just as a legal transaction, and moved up to Leon County, where they have lived since that time.
And now that's where the Beaumont oil wells are.
Oh, goodness.
So then your relatives were from, originally, like the Deep Sound.
Yes, from Mississippi and Alabama, and then prior to that, most of them came from the Carolinas before that time.
Okay, could you compare how your father and, like, say, your grandfather or even great-grandfather made their livings?
Yes.
Now, when those, the, my father...
made his living, he was raised on the farm.
I believe the acreages that were given out as land grants were about 108 acres each.
And both my mother's family and my father's family had a 108-acre plot.
I suppose they homesteaded this land.
I don't know if they had to pay for it or if it was given to them.
But they were both raised on this land.
There they raised almost everything that they used.
They were almost self-sufficient.
This little community where they grew up is about 35 miles from Brownlee.
And twice each year, they would come in wagons
to get the supplies that they had to have other than what they grew on their farms.
Now, their principal income, I think, was cotton.
They could raise two to three to four bales of cotton a year.
This is hand planted, hand cultivated, hand picked cotton done by the family itself.
maybe some corn for their livestock.
They had fruit trees, large gardens, chickens, and beef and pork that they raised for themselves.
The only things they really needed to buy were flour and sugar and coffee and candy.
this sort of thing.
So they grew up in a rural community where they did everything they could themselves as far as their own livelihood.
Then my father and my mother left the farm soon after they were married and my father did various jobs all throughout his life.
He had only
an elementary education, and he lived in different areas.
They lived in Dallas and where I was born in Freestone County and then back in Madison and Leon County.
All their lives, he did many things.
He owned several grocery stores.
He owned several service stations.
He worked as a very young man as an ice delivery boy in Dallas.
He worked in a tin shop as a young man.
Finally, in his later years, he was a wholesale distributor for Mobil Air, most of my growing up years.
enjoyed this very much.
Before he went with Mobil in the 30s, I believe it was the late 20s or early 30s, there was an oil field which came into being in East Texas around Kilgore and Longview.
And with the coming of this oil well, they produced cheaper gasoline than the major oil companies.
And
He was in business for himself for several years during the Depression.
My family was not really affected as much as a lot of others because he used this opportunity.
He had his own wholesale truck and he had a chain of service stations that he serviced with this cheaper gasoline that people needed very much at the time of the Depression.
and made quite a bit of money at that time for the times.
Well, in general, how do you feel that the Depression affected this general area?
Do you have any sort of feeling about that?
Well, I can remember the Depression very well, or the times.
I know people were so much more conservative in their living.
There were a lot of people roaming the country at that time, just as they were termed tramps.
You never hear that word much anymore, but they were single men who were out of work.
So many, you'd see them on the highways, and you'd see them riding on trains and boxcars, and they would just go from town to town looking for work or looking for...

something to eat i can remember many people coming to my mother's back door not never the front but to the back of the back door and asked for something to eat and my mother felt that maybe they were contact points in a town that because she had so many that maybe one would tell another
But she never refused anybody anything to eat.
But you never see this type thing now.
And they were white men.
I never remember seeing a black person going from door to door asking for something to eat.
I remember one Sunday in particular, it was about 1936.
someone knocked at our back door, and my mother went to the door, and it was a young man in his mid-twenties, and asked if he might have something to eat.
My mother, of course, never let someone in the house, because she was afraid to, and my dad was gone.
And she latched the door, screaming, and of course, at that day, there was so much less violence than there is now.

and she fixed him a sandwich or something to eat and as he turned to walk away she could see that all of his pockets filled with something to eat that he was stocking up from or maybe he was getting something for a friend but um the depression it's hard for me to say it didn't affect my family
Because of this opportunity that my dad took at that time, we probably lived
as well or better during the Depression as any other time in my life.
But others, I know, were affected, and it made an entirely different kind of atmosphere with the people.
I think it was a real sobering, had a real sobering effect on the people, which we may need some of that today.
Okay, do you remember anything about, like, the type of house your grandparents lived in, you know, as compared to the house that you grew up in?
Yes.
Now, my daddy's, in fact, my daddy was born in a log cabin.
His father built this log cabin when they came to Texas from Arkansas.
I don't know if it was a one room, or I think it was, but it was very, very well constructed, my dad said, because he tore it down later.
And he worked, it was put together with pegs, or in some way, it was almost impossible to tear it down.
But he was born in this log cabin, and I do think it had just a dirt floor.
And this is where they lived.
when they first came to Texas.
And then after, I don't know how long a period of time, I suppose whenever the time permitted for them to build a better house.
But the type of houses they lived in, they were wooden houses with usually just one or two large rooms with a fireplace.
And then sometimes the kitchens were detached so that you
stepped down and then back up into this other room for the kitchen.
I can remember seeing a house with a detached kitchen.
And I believe an elderly aunt of mine lived in it.
And for the step between the main house and the kitchen, there was a big tree stump, big round tree stump.
And you step down on that.
and then back up into the kitchen.
And I'm not sure what the purpose of this was, unless it was the heat in the summer to keep the other house from being so hot.
Or if it was for sanitary purposes, I'm not sure.
But I can remember my dad telling how much fun it was as a little boy to watch the men build chimneys.
And any time someone needed a house built in the community,
All the men went and helped the women cook food.
It was just a real fun time to do this.
But the most fun was the chimney.
They were mud chimneys made with moss off the trees.
They'd make mud, a big wet mud bat, and then take what he called little bats.
They would make the mud bats.
They would probably be about the size of a brick now, or maybe not as thick.
But they'd take moss and dip it into this mud and form it as best they could into some kind of a solid and put it out to dry.
Or maybe they didn't even dry it.
They may have just stacked it.
Mm-hmm.
On poles, on the frame, they'd build a chimney frame, and the moss would hold the mud together.
And they'd stack them on the chimney, and I suppose it dried then to solidify it.
And they had coated it on the outside with mud.
And how this kept from washing away, I don't know.
Maybe they put something on it to keep it from it.
But their houses were, the floors, I know he said, were just sort of rough.
wood, all the lumber was real rough in that day.

The floors were rough, and the way his mother cleaned the floors, she would put sand in sometimes on the floors at certain times of the year for special house cleaning, and had a real strong broom, and they would scour with the sand and wash it away, and this would help sand the roughness of the floors, and over a period of years, the floors would get smooth.
You know.
Oh.
But their houses were all very, very simple wood houses with a porch across the front.
And sometimes there would be holes in the floors and they were not airtight.
And the fireplace was usually their only source of heat.
Is that the type of house you grew up in?
No.
Now here's when I
Of course, we had, by that time, there were all the conveniences, the indoor bathrooms, the electricity, gas heating, that sort of thing, and carpeting.
Oh, so you grew up in a more modern-time house.
A modern-time house.
Now, I grew up in a very small community, and the houses were not...
not as nice of course as they are today.
But they were very comfortable.
I see.
We used space heaters in the house where I grew up.
Space gas heaters.
There was no central heating and there was no air conditioning.
And I think the real luxury
that I can remember as a child was being able to have an electric fan on when you slept at night.
That was the most luxurious thing you could have.
The heating was very modern by that time, but the electric air conditioning didn't come into being.
It was not really prevalent until I was homeschooled.
What types of general changes has there been in, say, livelihood activities from the time you grew up to the present?
Are there more people or fewer people farming?
Or if there are fewer people, what are these other people doing?
Just the general types of occupation.
When I was growing up, there were...

very few occupations to choose from if you what I mean your choice of occupation was very limited whereas now a young person going to college has so many choices that it probably is hard for them to decide what to do but choices were very very limited and in my area uh farming and ranching ranching became
more popular than farming as I was growing up because the price of beef began to go up after the Depression and during World War II and later.
And people did really become quite wealthy off of beef cattle in my day just simply because they did have the land.
I can remember the transition from farming to ranching.
they introduced coastal Bermuda grass into this part of the country.
In fact, my husband's father was a grass specialist, and he brought both St. Augustine and coastal Bermuda into this country.
But that made such a difference in cattle raising, and people began to improve their land
to fertilize their grass and to sprig it with coastal Bermuda.
This was an expensive process at that time, it seemed.
But people began doing this and improving fences.
And until now, that little rural community over there is just a beautiful area with such beautiful brick homes.
And their land is so well cared for.
Where at one time it had been the part that was not used for farming had just been thicket or not good for anything.
But the people had cleared it with large equipment, heavy equipment, and left just enough trees for shade.
And it sprigged with coastal Bermuda.
And that whole area almost is ranching now.
And Rockport's right at the moment.
The price of beef has gone down, so this has really hurt them, and I'm sure this is probably a temporary thing.
Can you think of any other techniques or innovations in farming or ranching, you know, that have really made a big, big difference besides the new grasses?
Like different types of irrigation?
Now there were a few cotton farmers still left over in that part of the country and of course around here we still had cotton farmers and now you have to be
You have to operate on a pretty large scale if you're in the cotton business.
There are no more small cotton farmers.
And irrigation has really helped in this area as far as cotton is concerned.
They control the growth.
And of course the mechanization of the kickers.
So they can operate on just very large scales.
And the cotton industry is controlled by just a few families who still operate that type of thing.
And with cattle, of course inoculations and the improvement of feed.
and that sort of thing.
Now, something interesting that over where I grew up, there were people who raised hogs.
And they raised them in parts of the country that were just real wooded, that was not really good for anything else.
And people, I know some people who became wealthy off of these wild hogs.
They bred in there, and they had no care
During the year, they lived off of acorns and whatever else they could scrounge for food because they were a hardy type, almost wild animal.
And then at certain times of the year, once or maybe twice, they'd go in there and round up those hogs and take them to market and sell them.
And the meat was not nearly so good as the corn-fed or...
But back in my youth, this was not as important as it is now.
And people, this was just clear profit.

All you had to do was, if you could manage to keep from getting killed by them, you'd round them up and take them in, and it would make quite a profit if you had a large herd of hogs that you had in the market.
Coming into town only twice a year for all your supplies and then not coming back.
Well, my dad had so many interesting things to tell.
It was just the highlight of the year to come to Bryan.
They came in wagons.
I'm not sure if they were covered or plain, probably depending on whether it was what type of year, what kind of time of year it was.
But it would take all day.
to drive to Brown in a wagon.
And Brown at that time had a large wagon yard on the north end near Main Street, the north end of the business district there.
And wagons that came in would park there and spend the night.
And then you could shop and visit around town.
And my dad talks, my dad's father died when he was two, but he had some grown brothers and sisters.
My daddy was born when his youngest sister was 17 years old.
So he was quite an afterthought.
And his brothers, he grew up with brothers and their families, with his mother.
But he tells of the time that his brother brought him and his little nephew, who was about his age.

to Brian and with others, and they saw their first train coming to Brian, and he said it was the biggest thing he'd ever seen with lights, and that his brother had to hold their hands so tight to keep them from running away.
They were so scared of the train, but that was the most exciting thing.
Something my dad said that I remember, that when he grew up out in the country,
There was no sound.
There was no noise.
And in his later years, he felt that the noises of day-to-living really affected people in their personalities.
That he could play all day long outside and never hear anything except locusts or crickets or birds.
There were no sounds.
There was not even a train whistle from where he lived.
There was no noise.
And the people's personalities were much calmer, much, they were just real different.
And as he grew older,
keep the noise of everything we do, the children who grow up with noise always in their home, with TVs, with stereos, radios, this must affect their personalities.
I never thought about how quiet it must have been.
My dad tells about the time, talking about the cotton.
They would bring their cotton.
They would have to carry their cotton to cotton gins.
At some point, they didn't bring them all the way to Brine, but they would take them, it would be quite a ways to the nearest cotton gin, several miles.
So when they would get them,
wagon full of cotton.
They would tie cotton sheet over it to protect it until they were ready to take it to the gym, which might be a day or two later.
And my daddy's grandmother came from Alabama
in her very late years to live with my daddy and his mother.
And she had become senile.
And at that time, there was no place, nothing that you could do for mental patients, or very few places to handle mental patients.
And she was just, as we know now, it's just hardening of the arteries, and had become senile.
And they had a

a room, one of the rooms in the house that they boarded the windows and fixed so that if she got to the front door, she began talking about running away, they could put her in there and lock her up if they had to do something and work if they weren't able to watch her all the time so they know she wouldn't get lost.
And she lived with them for several years.
And my dad talked, she must have been in her 80s or quite elderly, but he said she could run like a deer.
And if she wanted to get away,

Then he would have, it was his job, if she ever got away from him, she'd just decide all of a sudden that she didn't always want to run away, but there were times when she was going to do something and they'd try to keep her from going and then she'd run.
And they had barbed wire fences.
And he said she could just outrun him and run and get to a barbed wire fence and lie down and roll under it and jump up on the other side and run off.
And when he did catch her,
He'd have to get her back through that chance.
And she was such a hard thing to handle.
But as he grew up as a little boy, this was one of the part of his life.
Well, then this was his mother's mother.
Then his father's father came from Arkansas for a period of time and lived with him.
And he was a very old man.
And he was, in his old age, he was a basket weaver.
And he loved to, and he made a little bit of money along selling baskets because at times they picked cotton in baskets.
And they used them for all sorts of things on the farms.
And people would buy them from him.
And he watched them as a little boy.
And he would go out into the wooded area
and pick out a small tree and bring it home.
And then he would strip it into very thin strips.
He would peel thin strips of wood off this tree down to the very middle.
And then he'd soak the strips of wood in something until they were soft, and he made baskets.
And the basket man, my great-grandfather,
was married three times.
He outlived three wives.
And by the last marriage he had of his last child,
